It's not as if he's on TV taking up a slot that could be filled with something better; YouTube is practically infinite. It's really easy to not watch things that you don't like. If the most popular YouTuber does a video on a game you love, then you should be happy.

Snark notwithstanding though, I do hope it gives the sales numbers an extra bump, I don't see anything wrong with paid promotion, once it's disclosed.

I'm reminded of a study where they took the same set of songs that had no record deals, and allowed various groups to listen to any of them (there were too many for any one person to listen to all of them) and recommend them (online, within the group, like a yelp review or something).

Feedback loops setup, and certain songs became much more popular than other... but if you repeated the experiment with a different randomly selected group, a different set of songs became very popular... and so on... then they did a control where people couldn't recommend and influence what songs others listened too.

The conclusion was that it was nearly random chance what became popular and what didn't, and there was no strong correlation with people's personal preferences in the absensce of influence for others.

It basically confirms the idea that some people are famous for being famous, and some things are popular because they are popular.

I'm sure thats what has occurred with pewdiepie.

I highly doubt he is any more deserving of his success than a vast multitude of other people that post stuff on youtube.
